name: Universal point set
implication_form: If a graph is planar and has n vertices, then it can be drawn using a universal point set of order n.
explained: The Universal Point Set conjecture states that for every positive integer n, there exists a set S of n points in the Euclidean plane such that every n-vertex planar graph can be embedded as a straight-line drawing using only points from S. This means that a single set of points can be used to draw all possible n-vertex planar graphs with straight edges, without any two edges crossing (except at vertices). The conjecture is still unproven for all n.
related_conjectures: Existence of Universal Sets for Different Embeddings
